awd_titl_txt: Nanophotonic Strategies for Making Molecular Movies of Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
In this study, supported by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A), Chemical Catalysis (CAT) and Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Randall Goldsmith and his research team at the University of Wisconsin Madison seek to better understand how chemical catalysts perform their important functions.  Catalysts allow difficult chemical reactions to be proceed, but how they do this may involve many individual steps that are difficult to follow.  Professor Goldsmith is using a new approach that combines optical microscopy, the light-emitting behaviors of certain molecules (in this case, a property called "fluorescence"), and nanotechnology to to allow observation of single catalyst molecules.  The Goldsmith team is essentially developing "molecular movies" of an individual operational catalysts. This research project is not only providing new insights into catalytic chemical reactions, but also developing a laboratory technique that may be useful in many other chemistry, biology and materials science investigations.  The students involved in this research are gaining a wide range of skills, from chemical synthesis, optical microscopy, and nano-fabrication.
 
In particular, the project focuses on palladium cross-coupling reactions, which are widely employed in the pharmaceutical industry. A critical element is the use of nanophotonic devices that sculpt light to make it substantially smaller than the diffraction-limit, allowing observation of single-molecule dynamics at chemically relevant concentrations.  Individual catalyst molecules are immobilized in these devices and studied via single-molecule fluorescence microscopy.  A major readout is the time-varying rate constant of a single catalyst molecule and the timescale of transient intermediates.  The broader impacts of this work include the societal benefits of a mechanistic tool that can inform the design of the next generation of catalyst molecules, the training of students in interdisciplinary chemical sciences, and the development of single-molecule visualization demos that can be deployed in schools to broaden participation of STEM minorities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Homogenous catalysis involves multiple steps that can lead to the desired product, side reactions, or even catalyst decomposition. The specific bond formation and dissociation details are important to understanding the mechanism of product formation as well as where opportunities exist for designing better catalysts and catalytic systems. In bulk catalysis systems, molecule-to-molecule variability or rare events are hidden within the averaged behavior of the system. To observe rare catalysis events or subpopulations of catalysts, we developed a single molecule detection approach using nanophotonics and fluorescence detection. With this approach, the researchers can make “molecular movies” of individual catalysts to reveal their specific behavior.

At the heart of this effort is the use of Zero Mode Waveguides (ZMWs) to break the “concentration barrier” for performing single-molecule measurements at high concentration. ZMWs are nanophotonic devices consisting of 50-200 nm cylindrical holes in 100nm of aluminum on glass. In a review paper in ACS Measurement Science, “Strategies for Overcoming the Single-Molecule Concentration Barrier” we argued that ZMWs can be used to observe rare events that cannot be observed in bulk or in traditional low-concentration single-molecule experiments. Traditional single-molecule techniques have a concentration limit of 10nM, however ZMW experiments can use 1000x higher free ligand concentration, allowing for the observation of rare events like ligand rebinding to active catalysts.

In one set of experiments, we have succeeded in coupling single molecule fluorescence spectroscopy with ZMWs to detect individual steps of tethered catalysts involved in Negishi Couplings. Here, fluorescently-labeled catalysts are tethered in the bottom of the ZMW holes as determined by single-molecule wide-field fluorescence measurements. After initiation to dissociate the fluorescent “throw away” ligand to yield an active catalyst and then photobleaching any remaining intact catalysis molecules, a micromolar solution of fluorescently-labeled “throw away” ligand is introduced to the now mostly dark ZMW. About 5% of the catalysts rebind with a ligand and become fluorescent again, which is the first direct measurement of this hypothesized rebinding activity.

ZMWs have also been successfully applied to looking at biological dynamics.  In a paper published in Nature, supported students immobilized ion channels important for human pain response in ZMWs and used fluorescence microscopy to look at cooperativity in the binding of small molecules.  Despite earlier efforts implying indirectly that cooperativity should exist, we were able to show conclusively that cooperativity does not exist under these condition.  

Supported students also participated in two related efforts that made use of their background in fluorescence spectroscopy and chemical reaction dynamics. In one effort, students used the fluorescence output from an array of redox solutions to create a hybrid classical-molecular computer, a stepping stone to fully molecular computation as a potential alternative to in silico computing. They discovered that experimental noise from the setup can actually serve to shift the system out of local minima and improve the problem-solving ability of the computer. This story, “The Role of Experimental Noise in a Hybrid Classical-Molecular Computer to Solve Combinatorial Optimization Problems” was published in ACS Central Science. In another effort, supported students used their fluorescent microscopy setup to monitor the release of lithium ions from cathode microparticles by using a proxy fluorophore that only becomes fluorescent in the presence of lithium ions. The resulting “molecular movies” show highly inhomogeneous release kinetics in a manner that is uncorrelated with particle geometry as determined by SEM images of the cathode particles.

Extensions of the approaches and expertise developed in this work lead to several broader impacts. Undergraduates and graduate students developed a hands-on outreach activity that uses the commercial inexpensive origami microscope, Foldscope, to visualize subcellular fluorescence from leaf samples, an activity that has been disseminated to science teachers through a workshop at UW-Madison. Participants can observe fluorescence from plant leaves, which contain fluorescent chlorophyll visible through the Foldscope, using a white LED excitation source. Participants capture images of this fluorescence with their cell phone cameras as the detector. The teachers gave the activity an average rating of 4.8 out of 5. Several indicated that it would be directly applicable to the Next Generation Science Standards around the electromagnetic spectrum. Multiple graduate students participated in the Summer Science Camp organized by the Morgridge Institute for Research. Students ran single molecule demonstrations for high school students from rural areas in Wisconsin. This included a short lecture on fluorescence and the importance of single molecule studies, as well as a tour of the microscopy lab. The high school students then looked through the objective of an inverted microscope and observed individual rhodamine 6G molecules blinking in the field of view. Further, one student worked on the editorial board of the UW-Madison Chemistry Department’s art magazine (‘The Benzine’), the goal of which is to cultivate creativity and community in our department. The same student has volunteered has for both regional and state Fine Arts challenge programs.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: Randall H Goldsmith
